page.title: 04History in Bramdean
page.content: Bramdean was first placed on record under the name 'Bradandene' in AD908. The name means 'the broad valley'. It was also mentioned in the original Domesday Book as 'Brondean'. It was close to the Pilgrim's Way from Winchester to Canterbury. Centuries later the Cromwellian forces occupied the village. In the early 19th century the remains of a Roman Villa were discovered, but the mozaic floor has been lost with time. The church dates from the 12th century and traces of 2 Norman windows were discovered in 1985. There are several beautiful old manor houses and numerous cottages and residences of an interesting and historical nature. The village retains its old world charm despite the nearness of the busy A272 road
